area_name: f. Off Limits & Reach Around Walls

content.description: An attractive piece of rock that you've probably walked past countless times. Smeary/fingery moves between good stances. You can climb directly up the arete (+/- a foot or two on either side of course), but the more natural line - and the one you want if you're leading - is to follow the shallow left-facing corner just to the R of the arete.
content.protection: Your choice of big trees up top for your TR anchor; 40' of static rope needed. If you lead this, you'll want your smallest cams for the opening moves. I found Tricams especially well suited to protect the move off the ledge at 2/3 height, but YMMV.
content.location: It's immediately to your right as you head to the top of the hill on the trail that's 40 yds left of First Day.

content.description: Excellent route in a right-facing corner system, with two cruxes.
content.protection: Adequate.  Bolted anchor at top of cliff.  Easy walkoff.
content.location: Start in a right-facing corner approx 50 feet right of First Day; the base of the cliff is somewhat open there.  Follow corner system through two roofs to the top.

content.description:
Follow the crack system past several bulges to a shallow dihedral.  

  Well protected, and a bit strenuous; there is some loose rock on this route, but it can be avoided.
content.location: Six feet or so left of the start of First Day.

content.description: Who says Peterskill is climbed out?  A big move off the ground leads to more reasonable climbing, mostly near the arete.  Ends with a gear anchor about where Crack-a-Lack tops out.
content.protection: A tad runout on the much easier rock of the last 20' but otherwise it's G rated. It just doesn't look that way from below! Small cam (I found a #0 Metolius to be especially mind-calming) to #3 Camalot. Typical rack in other words.
content.location: Starts on the face right of C-a-L; 5 ft left of the arete to be precise. Go up 12' or so, step to R side of arete for a few moves, then back left to a big mantle about a bodylength below a broad ledge. Finish easily up and left. An ALTERNATIVE START would be to start on the right side of the arete and join the route about 10-12 ft up. I'd call it a 5.6 line if you go this way.

content.description: Thin and facey, then thin and traversy, then thin and bulgy.  Regardless, it's... scarce.  The route isn't too bad up to the traverse and small roof, but the crux is tres difficult.
content.protection: Unknown.  Gear anchor, or use bolts from Reach Around and use a directional.  DO NOT attempt to run this route off only the Reach Around bolts; the higher you get, the worse your pendulum will be.  Case in point -- I saw someone pull the crux, come off, and break their ankle when they hit the right-facing corner of Reach Around.
content.location: Start in corner of open book, traverse right up obvious crack in face to small right overhang, go right two feet, up through roof to top.

content.description: There are two ways to do this route, once past the huge horizontal offwidth: left open book goes 5.7, right open book goes 5.8.
content.protection: Adequate.  Can sling large boulder for anchor, and put in additional pieces under it.  The only trees in the vicinity are Pitch Pines.
content.location: Climb left side (left-facing corner) of cut-out area straight up to huge horizontal, then take your pick of open books -- left side, or right side.

content.description: I hated this route when I climbed it.  However, I may have been a bit offroute, so I won't condemn it completely until I can climb it again.
content.protection: Unknown.  Gear only anchor -- use large boulder.
content.location: Climb right-facing corner 6 feet right of First Day to top of block, step around to right, climb face above block to top.

content.description: A "Directissima" option to Broken Pedal.  Climb Broken Pedal to the ledge, then power straight over the overhang.
content.protection: Adequate protection.  Large block for anchor.

content.description: Climbs the left side of the prow that forms the initial corner of Reach Around. There's nice pumpy climbing on positive holds, and it's a good way to get another climb in if you're doing Reach Around. Did I mention it's PUMPY?
content.protection: TR only due to some potentially poor rock low on the route (though I haven't pulled anything off yet).  Don't anchor off the bolts - you want to be a good 8' left of there.
content.location: Starts about 6' left of the normal start to Reach Around. Climb the left side of that prow (crux at about 15 ft) until you can step left to a rest in an alcove of clean blond rock. Exit straight up or maybe a tad rightwards from there.

pathTokens: f. Off Limits & Reach Around Walls

content.description: Home to a few harder routes, and a double-bolted anchor. Generally occupied.
